intro: Triticum vulgare var. miltura, commonly known as millet, is a small grain plant belonging to the grass family Poaceae. It is characterized by its compact stature, typically growing to a height of 30–100 cm, and its ability to thrive in a variety of soil types. The plant produces small, clustered inflorescences called panicles, which bear numerous tiny grains. Millet is well adapted to arid and semi-arid climates, making it a drought-resistant crop. It is widely cultivated for its edible grains, which are used in various culinary traditions around the world.
